question:
Apple II is an example of _____ Generation of computer.

CHSL Exam 2022 Tier I
solution:
• Apple II computer belongs to the Fourth Generation of computers.
  • Fourth Generation computers used microprocessors as their central processing unit, which made them smaller, faster, and more efficient.
  • Apple II was one of the first successful personal computers (PCs) developed using microprocessor technology, launched in the late 1970s.

Additional Information:

  • First Generation computers used vacuum tubes.
  • Second Generation used transistors.
  • Third Generation used integrated circuits (ICs).
  • Fourth Generation started around 1971 with the development of the microprocessor, leading to personal computers like Apple II.

question:
Which among the following generations of Computer used vacuum tubes?

CHSL Exam 2022 Tier I
solution:
• The First Generation of computers used vacuum tubes as their main electronic component.
  • Vacuum tubes acted as switches and amplifiers in these early computers.
  • First Generation computers were large, consumed a lot of power, and produced a lot of heat due to vacuum tube usage.

Additional Information:

  • Second Generation computers used transistors, which were smaller and more reliable than vacuum tubes.
  • Third Generation computers used integrated circuits (ICs).
  • Fourth Generation computers used microprocessors, enabling the development of personal computers.

question:
Which generation of computers used machine code as the programming language?

CHSL Exam 2022 Tier I
solution:
• The First Generation of computers used machine code as their programming language.
  • Machine code consists of binary instructions (0s and 1s) directly understood by the computer hardware.
  • Programming in machine code was very difficult and time-consuming because it was low-level and not human-friendly.

Additional Information:

  • Second Generation computers used assembly language, which is a low-level language but easier than machine code.
  • Third Generation computers introduced high-level programming languages like COBOL and FORTRAN.
  • Fourth Generation computers use advanced high-level languages and support modern programming techniques.

question:
Sheila remembers that once upon a time transistors were used in her computer. In which generation of computers were these used?

CHSL Exam 2022 Tier I
solution:
• Transistors were primarily used in the Second Generation of computers.
  • Transistors replaced vacuum tubes, making computers smaller, faster, more reliable, and energy-efficient.
  • This generation marked a significant improvement over the first generation in terms of speed and size.

Additional Information:

  • First Generation computers used vacuum tubes.
  • Third Generation computers used integrated circuits (ICs).
  • Fourth Generation computers used microprocessors.

question:
Which of the following is a second generation system?

CHSL Exam 2022 Tier I
solution:
• Honeywell 400 is an example of a Second Generation computer system.
  • Second Generation computers primarily used transistors instead of vacuum tubes, which made them smaller and more reliable.
  • Honeywell 400 was a transistor-based mainframe computer from the 1950s-60s era.

Additional Information:

  • Sun workstations are modern systems, belonging to much later generations.
  • Apple II is a Fourth Generation personal computer using microprocessors.
  • IBM notebooks are also modern devices from the Fourth Generation onwards.

question:
Which among the following is not an example of the 4th Generation of Computer?

CHSL Exam 2022 Tier I
solution:
• ICL 2900 is not an example of the Fourth Generation of computers.
  • ICL 2900 belongs to the Third Generation, which used integrated circuits (ICs) but not microprocessors.
  • Fourth Generation computers use microprocessors, which made computers smaller, faster, and more affordable.
  • STAR 1000, TRS-80, and Apple II are examples of Fourth Generation computers using microprocessor technology.

Additional Information:

  • Third Generation computers came after the transistor era and before microprocessors.
  • Fourth Generation computers started around 1971 with microprocessor development.
  • ICL (International Computers Limited) 2900 series was known for mainframe and minicomputer systems using ICs, not microprocessors.

question:
PARAM supercomputer belongs to which generation of computers?

CHSL Exam 2022 Tier I
solution:
• PARAM supercomputer belongs to the Fifth Generation of computers.
  • Fifth Generation computers focus on artificial intelligence (AI), parallel processing, and advanced computing technologies.
  • PARAM was developed in India by the Centre for Development of Advanced Computing (C-DAC) in the early 1990s.

Additional Information:

  • First Generation used vacuum tubes.
  • Second Generation used transistors.
  • Third Generation used integrated circuits.
  • Fourth Generation used microprocessors.
  • Fifth Generation emphasizes AI, quantum computing, and advanced architectures.

question:
LTE technology is used in which of the following generation of wireless technologies?

CHSL Exam 2022 Tier I
solution:
• LTE (Long Term Evolution) technology is used in 4G wireless technology.
  • LTE provides faster data speeds, improved network capacity, and better mobile internet experience compared to previous generations.
  • It supports high-speed internet, HD video streaming, and advanced mobile applications.

Additional Information:

  • 1G refers to the first generation of wireless technology, mainly for analog voice calls.
  • 2G introduced digital voice and basic data services like SMS.
  • 3G provided faster data transfer and internet access.
  • 4G with LTE greatly enhanced mobile broadband capabilities.

question:
Sir Tim Berners-Lee — a British computer scientist invented the revolutionary World Wide Web in _____.

CHSL Exam 2022 Tier I
solution:
• Sir Tim Berners-Lee, a British computer scientist, invented the revolutionary World Wide Web (WWW) in 1990.
  • The World Wide Web transformed the way information is accessed and shared over the internet globally.
  • It introduced concepts like web pages, hyperlinks, and browsers that made the internet user-friendly.

Additional Information:

  • Before the web, the internet was mostly used by researchers and academics with complex interfaces.
  • The invention of WWW led to the rapid growth of the internet and online services.
  • Tim Berners-Lee also developed the first web browser and web server.

question:
Graphical User Interface (GUI) was developed during which of the following generations of computer?

CHSL Exam 2022 Tier I
solution:
• Graphical User Interface (GUI) was developed during the Fourth Generation of computers.
  • Fourth Generation computers used microprocessors, enabling advanced features like GUI, which allows users to interact with computers through graphical icons and visual indicators instead of text commands.
  • GUI made computers more user-friendly and accessible to a wider audience.

Additional Information:

  • First Generation used vacuum tubes and had no GUI.
  • Second Generation used transistors with command-line interfaces.
  • Third Generation used integrated circuits but GUIs were still not common.
  • The development of GUI became popular with personal computers in the Fourth Generation.

question:
_______ is also known as electronic disk.

CGL 2022 Tier II Paper I
solution:
• Solid-State Drive (SSD) is also known as an electronic disk.
  • SSD stores data electronically using flash memory, without any moving parts like traditional hard disks.
  • It is faster, more durable, and consumes less power compared to mechanical hard drives.

Additional Information:

  • USB sticks and USB hard drives are external storage devices but may use either flash memory or traditional disks.
  • Network storage servers provide storage over a network but are not specifically electronic disks.
  • SSDs have become popular for their speed and reliability in computers and laptops.

question:
_______ is the oldest type of Central Processing Unit (CPU).

CGL 2022 Tier II Paper I
solution:
• The Single Core processor is the oldest type of Central Processing Unit (CPU).
  • Single Core CPUs have only one processing unit to execute instructions at a time.
  • Later generations introduced Dual Core, Triple Core, and Quad Core CPUs to improve performance by handling multiple tasks simultaneously.

Additional Information:

  • Dual Core CPUs have two cores, enabling better multitasking.
  • Triple Core and Quad Core CPUs have three and four cores respectively, further enhancing processing power.
  • Single Core processors were common in early computers and basic laptops.

question:
Which among the following generations of computer used the technology of transistors for the first time?

CGL 2022 Tier II Paper I
solution:
• The Second Generation of computers used the technology of transistors for the first time.
  • Transistors replaced vacuum tubes, making computers smaller, faster, more reliable, and energy-efficient.
  • This generation marked a major technological advancement over the first generation.

Additional Information:

  • First Generation computers used vacuum tubes.
  • Third Generation computers used integrated circuits (ICs).
  • Fourth Generation computers used microprocessors.

question:
Which of the following is not a magnetic disk?

CGL 2022 Tier II Paper I
solution:
• DVD is not a magnetic disk; it is an optical disk that uses laser technology to read and write data.
  • Winchester disk, Zip disk, and Disk pack are all types of magnetic disks that store data magnetically.
  • Magnetic disks use magnetic storage to record data on rotating platters.

Additional Information:

  • DVDs store data digitally using pits and lands readable by a laser beam.
  • Magnetic disks are commonly used for hard drives and removable storage.
  • Optical disks like DVDs and CDs are used for media distribution and archival storage.

question:
Which of the following is the time taken by the CPU to access a location in memory?

RRB NTPC Stage-II 13/06/2022 (Shift-1)
solution:
• The time taken by the CPU to read from or write to a memory location is called Memory Access Time.
  • It is the sum of the time required to locate the memory location and to transfer the data to/from the processor.
  • It is usually measured in nanoseconds (ns) and is an important factor in the performance of a computer system.

Additional Information:

  • Memory formatting time is not a valid technical term in CPU operations.
  • Instruction cycle refers to the time taken to fetch, decode, and execute an instruction.
  • CPU frequency refers to the number of cycles per second (measured in Hertz) and is related to CPU speed, not access time.

question:
The speed of a CPU can measured in _________.

RRB NTPC Stage-II 15/03/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The speed or clock rate of a CPU (Central Processing Unit) is measured in Hertz (Hz), typically in Megahertz (MHz) or Gigahertz (GHz).
  • 1 Megahertz (MHz) = 1 million cycles per second. This refers to how many instruction cycles the CPU can perform per second.
  • Higher MHz or GHz means the processor can execute more instructions in a shorter time, improving performance.

Additional Information:

  • Bits per second (Bps) is a unit for data transmission speed, not CPU speed.
  • Lux is a unit of illumination, not related to computing.
  • Horsepower is a unit of mechanical power, used in engines, not computers.

question:
Which of the following is NOT a type of personal computer?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 09/02/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• Mainframe Computer is not a type of personal computer; it is a powerful system used by large organisations for bulk data processing.
  • Desktop, Palmtop, and Laptop are all types of personal computers, designed for individual use.
  • Personal computers are generally used for tasks like document editing, browsing, or entertainment.

Additional Information:

  • Mainframes support hundreds or thousands of users simultaneously and are used in banks, government departments, and big corporations.
  • Palmtop is a handheld PC, also known as a PDA.
  • Laptop is a portable personal computer, and Desktop is a stationary one.

question:
From the following options, identify the name of the user interface element that is found on desktop as a small blinking symbol or an arrow.

RRB NTPC Stage-I 03/02/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The Cursor is the small blinking symbol (usually a vertical line or arrow) on the screen that indicates where the user’s next action will take place.
  • It appears in text areas as a blinking line and on desktops as an arrow or pointer for navigating.
  • It helps users interact with the user interface, like selecting icons, typing, or highlighting text.

Additional Information:

  • Shortcut is a link to a program or file.
  • Task-bar is the bar at the bottom of the screen showing open applications.
  • Icons are small graphical representations of programs or files on the desktop.

question:
A computer monitor is also known by the name:

RRB NTPC Stage-I 03/02/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• A computer monitor is also known as a VDU (Visual Display Unit).
  • It displays the output of processing done by the CPU in visual form, such as text, images, and videos.
  • It is an essential output device for interacting with the computer system.

Additional Information:

  • LED is a type of display technology used in monitors.
  • CPU is the central processing unit, the brain of the computer, not a display device.
  • CCTV is a closed-circuit television system used for surveillance, not for computing.

question:
Which of the following is NOT a part of the hardware of a computer?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 23/01/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• Microsoft Office is not a part of the hardware; it is a software suite that includes applications like Word, Excel, and PowerPoint.
  • Hardware refers to the physical components of a computer system, such as the monitor, keyboard, and CPU.
  • Software like Microsoft Office operates on the hardware to perform tasks.

Additional Information:

  • Monitor is a display hardware device.
  • Keyboard is an input hardware device.
  • CPU is the processing hardware component.

question:
Which of the following are the two components of the CPU of a computer?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 03/04/2021 (Shift-I)
option_2: Control unit and ALU
option_3: Control unit and Bus
option_4: Registers and Main memory
solution:
• The two main components of the CPU are the ALU (Arithmetic Logic Unit) and the Control Unit.
  • The ALU performs all arithmetic and logical operations such as addition, subtraction, comparison, etc.
  • The Control Unit directs the operation of the processor by managing the flow of data between the CPU and other parts of the computer.

Additional Information:

  • A Bus is a communication system for transferring data.
  • Registers are small storage units within the CPU.
  • Main memory (RAM) is not part of the CPU but works closely with it.

question:
The CPU is called the:

RRB NTPC Stage-I 02/03/2021 (Shift-II)
option_1: Lung of the computer
option_2: Brain of the computer
option_3: Heart of the computer
option_4: Backbone of the computer
solution:
• The CPU is known as the Brain of the Computer because it performs all processing tasks.
  • It interprets and executes instructions from hardware and software.
  • All calculations, logical decisions, and data flow are controlled by the CPU.

Additional Information:

  • Lungs analogy is not used in computer terminology.
  • Heart is sometimes used for the power supply, not CPU.
  • Backbone often refers to the motherboard or network infrastructure, not CPU.

question:
Which of the following is a component of Central Processing Unit?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 25/01/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• Memory is a component that works closely with the CPU and is often considered part of the processing system.
  • It stores data and instructions temporarily while the CPU processes them.
  • Though technically memory is separate, it is a critical internal component of the system architecture supporting CPU functions.

Additional Information:

  • Mouse, Monitor, and Keyboard are input/output devices, not internal CPU components.
  • The CPU itself primarily consists of the ALU, Control Unit, and Registers, but memory like cache or RAM is tightly integrated in functionality.

question:
A microphone converts-

RRB NTPC Stage-I 21/01/2021 (Shift-II)
option_1: Mechanical energy into sound energy
option_2: Sound energy into mechanical energy
option_3: Electrical energy into sound energy
option_4: Sound energy into electrical energy
solution:
• A microphone converts sound energy into electrical energy.
  • When you speak into a microphone, the sound waves cause a diaphragm inside it to vibrate, which is then converted into an electrical signal.
  • This electrical signal can be amplified, recorded, or transmitted.

Additional Information:

  • Speakers do the reverse by converting electrical energy back into sound.
  • Microphones are classified as input devices in a computer system.

question:
Global weather forecasting is done by using.

RRB NTPC Stage-I 07/04/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• Super Computers are used for global weather forecasting because they can process massive amounts of data at very high speeds.
  • Weather models involve complex mathematical calculations and real-time data from satellites, which require the immense processing power of supercomputers.
  • These systems can simulate climate patterns and predict natural phenomena like storms and cyclones.

Additional Information:

  • Mini Computers are used for mid-level tasks, not global forecasting.
  • Hybrid Computers combine analogue and digital features but are used in specialised control systems.
  • Micro Computers (like desktops) are meant for individual users, not high-level scientific processing.

question:
What are the peripheral devices?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 23/02/2021 (Shift-I)
option_1: Those that connect computer to the internet
option_2: Those that help in calculation
option_3: These devices help in storing and analyzing data
option_4: These are internal or external device that connect directly to a computer but do not contribute to the computer’s primary functions
solution:
• Peripheral devices are external or internal devices that connect to a computer but are not directly involved in its core processing functions.
  • They include devices like mouse, keyboard, printer, scanner, and external drives.
  • These devices help with input, output, and storage functions but not with actual computing or processing tasks.

Additional Information:

  • Examples of input peripherals: keyboard, mouse, scanner.
  • Examples of output peripherals: monitor, printer, speakers.
  • Storage peripherals: external hard drives, USB flash drives.

question:
How many output ports are there in peripheral I/O?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 07/01/2021 (Shift-I)
solution:
• In peripheral I/O (Input/Output), the number of output ports is typically 256.
  • This is based on the addressing capability of an 8-bit port address, which can range from 0 to 255, giving a total of 256 output ports.
  • It allows the CPU to communicate with various output devices like printers, monitors, etc.

Additional Information:

  • This standard is followed in traditional I/O-mapped I/O systems, especially in older or embedded architectures.
  • Similarly, 256 input ports are also typically available, making the total I/O addressable range 512.

question:
Which of the following is not a part of a personal computer?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 16/01/2021 (Shift-I)
solution:
• USB (Universal Serial Bus) is an interface or port, not an actual component of the internal architecture of a personal computer.
  • It is used to connect external devices like pen drives, keyboards, or printers to the computer.
  • Components like CPU, RAM, and ROM are internal and essential parts of a personal computer.

Additional Information:

  • CPU is the central processing unit that handles all processing tasks.
  • RAM (Random Access Memory) is temporary memory for active tasks.
  • ROM (Read Only Memory) contains permanent instructions like the boot program.

question:
Who is considered the father of computers?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 08/01/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• Charles Babbage is known as the Father of Computers due to his invention of the Analytical Engine in the 1830s.
  • The Analytical Engine had components similar to modern computers: an ALU, control unit, and memory.
  • Though it was never fully built during his lifetime, the design laid the foundation for future computing systems.

Additional Information:

  • Charles Bachman developed database management systems.
  • John Atanasoff co-invented the first electronic digital computer (ABC).
  • Alan Turing was a pioneer in theoretical computer science and artificial intelligence.

question:
Modern computers follow a set of instructions to perform any task. These instructions can be better known as.

RRB NTPC Stage-I 25/01/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• Modern computers perform tasks by following a set of instructions called Programs.
  • A program is a collection of coded instructions written in a programming language that the computer can understand and execute.
  • These programs control the behaviour of the computer to perform specific operations like calculations, data processing, or system control.

Additional Information:

  • Commands are individual instructions, often given through the command line.
  • Language refers to programming languages like C, Java, Python, etc., used to write programs.
  • Guidelines are general suggestions or best practices, not executable instructions.

question:
Which of the following chemical element, Tetravalent Metalloids, is used to make an integrated circuit (IC) chip used in computers?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 30/04/2016 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The element used to make Integrated Circuit (IC) chips is Silicon.
  • Silicon is a tetravalent metalloid, meaning it has four valence electrons and shows properties of both metals and non-metals.
  • It is widely used in the electronics industry due to its excellent semiconducting properties, making it ideal for manufacturing microchips and processors.

Additional Information:

  • Gold and Silver are good conductors but are too expensive for widespread IC use.
  • Copper is used in electrical wiring and some circuit tracks but not as the base material for IC chips.
  • Silicon is the basis of semiconductors, and most chips are made using silicon wafers.

question:
A serial port can do-

RRB NTPC Stage-I 27/04/2016 (Shift-II)
option_1: Transfer information from hard drive only
option_2: Transfer information to hard drive only
option_3: Both a and b
solution:
• A serial port is a type of interface that transfers data one bit at a time over a single communication line.
  • It can both send and receive data, which means it can transfer information to and from a hard drive, or more generally, to and from connected devices.
  • So, options (a) and (b) are both valid, making (c) Both a and b the correct answer.

Additional Information:

  • Serial ports were commonly used to connect devices like modems, mice, and external storage devices.
  • Although largely replaced by USB ports today, serial ports still exist in some specialised systems and industrial computers.

question:
Computer can not work without-

RRB NTPC Stage-I 27/04/2016 (Shift-II)
solution:
• A computer cannot function without the CPU (Central Processing Unit), which is the core component responsible for processing instructions.
  • The CPU performs all major tasks like calculations, decision-making, and managing data flow.
  • Without the CPU, the computer is non-operational, as it has no way to execute commands.

Additional Information:

  • Scanner, Internet, and Mouse are peripheral or optional components.
  • A computer can still function without these, though user interaction may be limited.

question:
Any person known as “computer literate”. If he is capable only-

RRB NTPC Stage-I 19/01/2017 (Shift-II)
option_1: To run important applications
option_2: To make anti-virus softwares
option_4: To hack the computers
solution:
• A person is considered "computer literate" if they are capable of running important applications like word processors, spreadsheets, browsers, and other commonly used software.
  • Computer literacy means having basic knowledge and skills to operate a computer effectively in daily tasks.
  • It does not require programming or hacking skills.

Additional Information:

  • Writing programs and creating antivirus software require advanced technical skills, not basic computer literacy.
  • Hacking is illegal and unethical, and not a sign of literacy.

question:
Colour of Padlock in URL of any secure website is-

RRB NTPC Stage-I 18/04/2016 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The padlock icon in the URL bar of a secure website is typically green.
  • A green padlock indicates that the website uses HTTPS (HyperText Transfer Protocol Secure) and has a valid SSL/TLS certificate.
  • It ensures that the communication between your browser and the website is encrypted and secure.

Additional Information:

  • Some browsers now use a grey padlock instead of green but still indicate security.
  • A red padlock or warning sign may indicate an insecure or potentially harmful website.
  • The padlock symbol is a visual assurance of a secure connection, especially useful for banking and shopping sites.

question:
Meaning of MIPS in computer dictionary is-

RRB NTPC Stage-I 18/04/2016 (Shift-II)
option_2: Million instruction per second
option_3: Micro information processing state
option_4: Memory image processing state
solution:
• MIPS stands for Million Instructions Per Second.
  • It is a measure of the processing speed of a computer—specifically, how many million instructions the CPU can execute in one second.
  • MIPS is commonly used to compare the performance of different processors.

Additional Information:

  • It is a benchmarking unit, though modern systems often use GHz and more advanced metrics like FLOPS for performance.
  • Higher MIPS generally indicates a faster processor, but it doesn’t always reflect real-world efficiency.

question:
What is the second name of computer chip?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 28/03/2016 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The second name of a computer chip is Microchip.
  • A microchip is a small semiconductor module that contains integrated circuits, which are essential for electronic operations in a computer.
  • These chips are found in various computer components like the CPU, memory, and controllers.

Additional Information:

  • Motherboard is the main circuit board that connects all components.
  • CPU (Central Processing Unit) is a type of chip, but not all chips are CPUs.
  • Microprocessor is a specific type of chip used for processing, but the general term "computer chip" is best matched with microchip.

question:
What is the full name of BIOS?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 29/03/2016 (Shift-III)
option_1: Binary interchange operation system
option_2: Basic input output system
option_3: Binary input operation symbol
option_4: Basic interface oriented service
solution:
• The full form of BIOS is Basic Input Output System.
  • It is the firmware stored on a small memory chip on the motherboard, responsible for starting up the computer.
  • BIOS performs tasks like hardware initialization, checking connected devices, and loading the operating system from storage.

Additional Information:

  • BIOS runs when the computer is powered on—this is called the booting process.
  • It provides a low-level interface between the operating system and the hardware.
  • Modern systems use UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) as an advanced replacement of traditional BIOS.

question:
What is the work of BIOS?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 30/03/2016 (Shift-I)
option_1: To starting system hardware parts
option_2: To update the system
option_3: To ensuring system performance
option_4: To protect erashing of system
solution:
• The primary work of BIOS (Basic Input Output System) is to start and initialise the system hardware components when the computer is powered on.
  • It performs a process called POST (Power-On Self-Test) to check whether the hardware like RAM, keyboard, hard drive, etc., are functioning properly.
  • Once the checks are complete, BIOS loads the operating system from the storage into RAM to begin system operations.

Additional Information:

  • BIOS is stored in ROM on the motherboard and works before the operating system starts.
  • It provides the necessary instructions for communication between the OS and hardware.

question:
Which of the following is not related to the given group?

RRB Group-D 12/12/2018 (Shift-III)
solution:
• Among the given options, Basin Buddy is not related to computer hardware.
  • Hard disk, CPU, and Motherboard are all essential components of a computer system.
  • Basin Buddy is a non-technical term, possibly referring to a household item or cleaning tool, and has no association with computing or electronics.

Additional Information:

  • Hard disk is used for data storage.
  • CPU (Central Processing Unit) is the brain of the computer.
  • Motherboard connects all components of a computer together.

question:
Full name of VLSI is-

RRB NTPC Stage-I 17/01/2017 (Shift-III)
option_1: Very large scale integration
option_2: Village level system integration
option_3: Virtual light system information
option_4: Very fide large system integration
solution:
• The full form of VLSI is Very Large Scale Integration.
  • It refers to the process of integrating thousands to millions of transistors onto a single microchip.
  • VLSI technology is used to design microprocessors, RAM chips, and complex circuits found in modern computers and electronic devices.

Additional Information:

  • VLSI is a major advancement in electronics and allows for compact, fast, and powerful chips.
  • It evolved from earlier technologies like SSI (Small Scale Integration), MSI (Medium Scale Integration), and LSI (Large Scale Integration).

question:
Which of the following is not true about backup?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 19/04/2016 (Shift-I)
option_1: Exact copy of computer files
option_2: It is part of the business continuity plan
option_3: PC does not require regular backup
option_4: Backups are more beneficial on off sight and on sight
solution:
• The statement (b) "It is part of the business continuity plan" is actually true, so marking it as false is incorrect.
  • The correct incorrect statement is (c) "PC does not require regular backup", because regular backup is essential to protect data against loss from hardware failure, malware, or accidental deletion.
  • Therefore, the given answer 'b' is incorrect, and the correct answer should be (c).

Correct Answer:(c) PC does not require regular backup

Additional Information:

  • Backups are exact copies of important data files.
  • They are a crucial part of disaster recovery and business continuity planning.
  • Performing backups both on-site and off-site improves data safety.

question:
Data transmission speed is generally measure in which unit?

RRB SSE 21/12/2018
solution:
• Data transmission speed is generally measured in Bits per second (bps).
  • It indicates how many bits of data can be transmitted over a network or communication line each second.
  • Higher bps means faster data transfer, and common units include Kbps (kilobits/sec), Mbps (megabits/sec), and Gbps (gigabits/sec).

Additional Information:

  • Nanosecond is a unit of time, not speed.
  • Megahertz and Kilohertz measure frequency (cycles per second), often used for CPU speed or signal frequency—not for data transmission.

question:
In a microprocessor, when interference in CPU then-

RRB SSE 21/12/2014
option_1: Microprocessor stops execution of specification
option_2: Make the branches of subroutine accepting the blockage
option_3: Does not continue execution of specification after accepting the blockage
option_4: Continue execution of specification after accepting the blockage
solution:
• In a microprocessor, when an interference or interrupt occurs, the CPU temporarily halts the current execution and responds to the interrupt by executing a predefined interrupt service routine (ISR).
  • After completing the ISR, the CPU returns to the original task and continues execution of the specification from where it left off.
  • Therefore, the correct behaviour is: continue execution after accepting the blockage (interrupt).

Additional Information:

  • Interrupts are essential for handling input/output operations, system alerts, or errors without continuously checking for them.
  • There are two types of interrupts: hardware interrupts (from external devices) and software interrupts (triggered by instructions).

question:
Which of the following is not a register of computer?

RRB SSE 21/12/2014
solution:
• Buffer is not a register of a computer; it is a temporary memory storage area used to hold data while it is being transferred between two locations or devices.
  • Accumulator, Stack Pointer, and Program Counter are all internal registers in a CPU that help manage instruction execution and data processing.
  • Registers are small, high-speed memory locations within the CPU used for immediate data access and control.

Additional Information:

  • Accumulator holds intermediate arithmetic or logic results.
  • Stack Pointer tracks the top of the stack in memory.
  • Program Counter holds the address of the next instruction to be executed.
